verses.text: Do not quarrel with a powerful man, or you may fall into his hands.
verses.comment: Wisdom literature warns against fighting with those in authority, much as Jesus teaches humility and prudence (see Matt. 5:25). Practical wisdom upholds peace with others, foreshadowing Christ's teachings on reconciliation.

verses.text: Do not argue with a rich man, or you might lose your case. For gold has ruined many, and twisted the hearts of kings.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the danger of worldly wealth corrupting justice, paralleling warnings of Jesus in Luke 16:13. The emphasis is on spiritual integrity above earthly gain.

verses.text: Do not contend with a talkative person, and do not heap wood on his fire.
verses.comment: Escalating conflict with the argumentative brings no peace. This anticipates New Testament admonitions to leave unnecessary disputes (2 Tim. 2:23).

verses.text: Do not make fun of one who turns away from sin; remember that we are all worthy of punishment.
verses.comment: Respect for the repentant mirrors Christ's welcome of sinners (Luke 15:7). All are urged toward humility, as none are without sin (Rom. 3:23).

verses.text: Do not disrespect an old man, for some of us will also grow old.
verses.comment: Honor of elders is a sign of wisdom and continuity of tradition. The early Church respected those with experience, reflecting this teaching.

verses.text: Do not rejoice at someone’s death; remember that we all must die.
verses.comment: This aligns with the Christian teaching of compassion and the mystery of death, urging prayer for the departed and humility before judgment.

verses.text: Do not reject the advice of the wise, but reflect on their teachings, for you may learn from their instruction.
verses.comment: Receiving wisdom is foundational to spiritual growth; Christ built His Church on the witness and guidance of the apostles, passing on sound teaching (2 Tim. 2:2).

verses.text: Do not disregard the teachings of the elders, for they also learned from their fathers; they will teach you how to answer in time of need.
verses.comment: The relay of tradition from elders affirms apostolic succession and the authority passed through generations, a structure essential to the unity of the faithful (cf. Acts 14:23).

verses.text: Do not stir up a sinner, or you may be burned by his flames.
verses.comment: Tempting or provoking those inclined to sin endangers your own soul. Christian charity seeks not to tempt anyone but to lead to holiness.

verses.text: Do not argue with a hot-tempered man, and do not travel with him through the desert; for blood is nothing to him, and wherever there is no help, he will kill you.
verses.comment: Bad company leads to ruin. The Church teaches discernment in companionship, echoing Paul’s counsel (1 Cor. 15:33).

verses.text: Do not consult a fool, for he cannot keep a secret.
verses.comment: An exhortation toward seeking wise counsel, a virtue that is essential in both Old and New Testament living (James 3:13-18).

verses.text: Do not reveal your secrets to anyone who lacks discernment, for they will not keep your confidence.
verses.comment: Wise stewardship of knowledge safeguards relationships and the safety of the community. Jesus also taught prudence with speech (Matt. 7:6).

verses.text: Do not do wrong to your friend, nor lie to him in the presence of an enemy.
verses.comment: Honesty and loyalty are the foundation of true friendship, reflecting God’s faithfulness. Christ commands truthfulness (Matt. 5:37).

verses.text: Do not share your secrets with anyone except the wise and discreet, for what you share with them will not be lost.
verses.comment: The trusted stewardship of secrets anticipates the spiritual wisdom necessary for leading others. It echoes the principle of spiritual fatherhood found throughout the Scriptures.

verses.text: Do not envy a sinner’s prosperity, for you do not know what sort of ruin will come upon him.
verses.comment: Material success is not always a blessing; wisdom literature reminds us to focus on eternal rewards (see Matt. 6:19-21).

verses.text: Do not delight in the pleasures of the wicked; remember, they will not go unpunished to their graves.
verses.comment: This is a call to moral and spiritual seriousness—the way of the wicked leads only to destruction (see Gal. 6:7-8).

verses.text: Keep far from a man who has the power to kill, and you will not be tormented by the fear of death. But if you must approach him, do nothing that will offend him, for you may risk your life. Remember you are walking among traps, and you are treading on the edge of a city’s walls.
verses.comment: Prudence with those in power is wisdom; even Christ counseled discretion amid persecution (see Matt. 10:16-18).

verses.text: As much as possible, do not have dealings with a rash person, or visit the foolish, or consult the jealous woman about her rival. Do not open your heart to such people.
verses.comment: Associating with the unruly leads to folly. New Testament wisdom continues this counsel (2 Cor. 6:14-15).

verses.text: Do not reveal your thoughts to anyone, lest you be repaid with evil by your enemies.
verses.comment: Discretion is vital for spiritual and practical integrity. Jesus Himself often kept silence among adversaries (see Luke 23:9).
